p.s: The one-act play Disgraced, Scene 4 was written by the American author Ayad Akhtar and published in 2012.
It deals with the deep effects of racism and Islamophobia and appeals to be aware of the difficulties Muslim Americans face on a day-to-day basis.
The setting of the play is an apartment on New York's Upper East Side in 2011.
Scene 4 takes place six months after the huge fight with Isaac and Jory and Amir beating his wife Emily.
Emily and Abe come over to the apartment.

Abe tells his uncle Amir about how he and his friend Tariq got arrested and interrogated by the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation, as they were suspicious of the boys having ties to Islamistic terrorism.
While checking Abe's immigration status, who recently immigrated from Pakistan, the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation realized that it was up for renewal.
Amirimmediatlyimmediately calls Ken, the lawyer of Imam Fareed.
He reminds Abe about how being muslim is not a neutral fact anymore and that he should be aware of that.
However, Abe clearly states that he would not work for the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation as he is not on their side.
After reminding Abe that he could get deported, the conversation gets tensed.
Abe talks about how they should have never left Pakistan in the first place.
Being out of rage, he accuses his uncle of beating Emily and his problems at his working place.
Moreover, he tells Amir that he changed his name back to Hussein.

Getting emotional, Abe continues insulting his uncle and talks about how the discrimination against Muslim people is going to come to an end, as they, as a Muslim community, are going to fight back to get what they deserve.
